title: Spark and Polars
text:
Spark to polars via arrow is memory efficient.

Found this on stackoverflow.
import pyspark
import polars as pl
import pyarrow as pa

def spark2polars(sdf: pyspark.sql.DataFrame):
    pdf = pl.from_arrow(pa.Table.from_batches(sdf._collect_as_arrow()))
    return pdf

title: UV
text:
Using uv to manage a virtual environment.

Install uv:
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
Create a virtual environment:
#!/usr/bin/env bash

set -e

echo "==> Creating venv"
uv venv .venv

echo "==> Activating venv"
source .venv/bin/activate

echo "==> Installing packages"
uv pip install ipykernel jupyterlab

echo "==> Creating jupyter kernel"
python -m ipykernel install --user --name=.venv --display-name="Python 3.12 (.venv)"

title: Git Worktree
text:
Manage multiple branches in a single repository.
git worktree comes built-in with git and allows you to have multiple branches checked out at the same time.
I like it for when I need to work on a feature branch and a hotfix branch at the same time.

title: Git Worktree
text:
Usage
Do I already have any worktrees?
git worktree list
Create a new worktree for a branch
Path for the worktree is .worktree/hotfix. Commit/branch to use in worktree is main.






Warning



You can’t checkout another branch in your parent repository if you have a worktree for that branch.


git worktree add -b .worktree/hotfix main
Switch to the worktree:
cd .worktree/hotfix
Do some work in the worktree:
git add ...
git commit ...
git push ...
Remove the worktree:
cd ../..
git worktree remove .worktree/hotfix
